channel.title: Nature News and Views
channel.description: News and Views articles from Nature Publishing Group journals

item.title: Well-matched vibrations cool electronic hot spots
item.description: Diamond layers can help to dissipate the heat generated by high-power semiconductor devices. This effect has now been enhanced by adding layers of materials and engineering their crystal-lattice vibrations to be compatible at the interfaces.
item.content:encoded: Diamond layers can help to dissipate the heat generated by high-power semiconductor devices. This effect has now been enhanced by adding layers of materials and engineering their crystal-lattice vibrations to be compatible at the interfaces.

item.title: ER remodelling by ER-phagy in neurogenesis
item.description: The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) controls the synthesis of lipids and proteins and Ca2+ homeostasis, as well as contacting other organelles and the plasma membrane. A study now looks at a process by which this compartment is remodelled in axons during neurogenesis: the lysosomal clearance of ER subdomains, driven by FAM134 and CCPG1 proteins.
item.content:encoded: The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) controls the synthesis of lipids and proteins and Ca2+ homeostasis, as well as contacting other organelles and the plasma membrane. A study now looks at a process by which this compartment is remodelled in axons during neurogenesis: the lysosomal clearance of ER subdomains, driven by FAM134 and CCPG1 proteins.
item.dc:creator: Maurizio Molinari
item.dc:title: ER remodelling by ER-phagy in neurogenesis

item.title: Targeting stromal metabolism in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma
item.description: The tumour microenvironment produces nutrients that propel cancer development. New work finds that pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cells use one such nutrient, acetate, to alter protein acetylation, rerouting polyamine metabolism and promoting cell growth under acidosis—a finding with potential implications for treating this cancer.
item.content:encoded: The tumour microenvironment produces nutrients that propel cancer development. New work finds that pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cells use one such nutrient, acetate, to alter protein acetylation, rerouting polyamine metabolism and promoting cell growth under acidosis—a finding with potential implications for treating this cancer.
item.dc:creator: Miao Yin
Qun-Ying Lei
item.dc:title: Targeting stromal metabolism in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma

item.title: Mesoscale condensates organize the cytoplasm
item.description: Biomolecular condensates are recognized for their ability to compartmentalize the cytoplasm without bounding membranes, but the degree to which they organize the cytoplasm has not been clear. A new study reveals that condensates at a scale of 100 nm are responsible for the organization of at least 18% of the cytoplasmic proteome.

Jonathon A. Ditlev
item.dc:title: Mesoscale condensates organize the cytoplasm

item.title: Synchronized neuronal activity drives waste fluid flow
item.description: Active neurons can stimulate the clearance of their own metabolic waste by driving changes to ion gradients in the surrounding fluid and by promoting the pulsation of nearby blood vessels.
item.content:encoded: Active neurons can stimulate the clearance of their own metabolic waste by driving changes to ion gradients in the surrounding fluid and by promoting the pulsation of nearby blood vessels.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hablitz
Maiken Nedergaard
item.dc:title: Synchronized neuronal activity drives waste fluid flow

item.title: Tiny sheaths of solvent boost battery performance
item.description: Small solvent molecules have been found to enable a previously unknown ion-transport mechanism in battery electrolytes, speeding up charging and increasing performance at low temperatures.
item.content:encoded: Small solvent molecules have been found to enable a previously unknown ion-transport mechanism in battery electrolytes, speeding up charging and increasing performance at low temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Chong Yan
Jia-Qi Huang
item.dc:title: Tiny sheaths of solvent boost battery performance

item.title: A mobile DNA sequence could explain tail loss in humans and apes
item.description: The lack of a tail is one thing that separates apes — including humans — from other primates. Insertion of a short DNA sequence into a gene that controls tail development could explain tail loss in the common ancestor of apes.
item.content:encoded: The lack of a tail is one thing that separates apes — including humans — from other primates. Insertion of a short DNA sequence into a gene that controls tail development could explain tail loss in the common ancestor of apes.

Emily L. Casanova
item.dc:title: A mobile DNA sequence could explain tail loss in humans and apes

item.title: Self-assembling synthetic polymer forms liquid-like droplets
item.description: The molecules of liquid crystals and proteins can form liquid-like condensates, but such a phenomenon had not been observed for supramolecular polymers, which are held together by non-covalent bonds — until now.
item.content:encoded: The molecules of liquid crystals and proteins can form liquid-like condensates, but such a phenomenon had not been observed for supramolecular polymers, which are held together by non-covalent bonds — until now.

item.dc:title: Self-assembling synthetic polymer forms liquid-like droplets

item.title: Quantum sensor settles debate about superconductivity in hydrides
item.description: By adapting a device designed to create extremely high pressures into one that can sense magnetic fields, researchers have obtained evidence that a hydrogen-rich material is a superconductor, eliminating long-standing doubts.
item.content:encoded: By adapting a device designed to create extremely high pressures into one that can sense magnetic fields, researchers have obtained evidence that a hydrogen-rich material is a superconductor, eliminating long-standing doubts.
item.dc:creator: Kin On Ho
Sen Yang
item.dc:title: Quantum sensor settles debate about superconductivity in hydrides

item.title: Non-neuronal brain cells modulate behaviour
item.description: A single gene in astrocytes can constrain repetitive behaviours, indicating that these cells are regulators of behavioural disruption in conditions such as Huntington’s disease and obsessive–compulsive disorder.
item.content:encoded: A single gene in astrocytes can constrain repetitive behaviours, indicating that these cells are regulators of behavioural disruption in conditions such as Huntington’s disease and obsessive–compulsive disorder.

item.title: Cellular neighborhood analysis in spatial omics reveals new tissue domains and cell subtypes
item.description: Spatial omics enables the molecular profiling of cells with the tissue context preserved. A new analytic approach shows how cellular neighborhood analysis and feature augmentation can spatially connect and cluster millions of cells into higher-order functional units.

item.dc:title: Cellular neighborhood analysis in spatial omics reveals new tissue domains and cell subtypes

item.title: New insights into the genetics of diabetes in pregnancy
item.description: Gestational diabetes is a complex metabolic condition thought to have a strong genetic predisposition. A large genome-wide association study of participants from Finland sheds light on the genetic contributors, opening avenues for research into mechanisms that underlie glucose regulation in pregnancy to improve the health of mothers and babies.
item.content:encoded: Gestational diabetes is a complex metabolic condition thought to have a strong genetic predisposition. item.dc:creator: Aminata Hallimat Cissé
Rachel M. Freathy
item.dc:title: New insights into the genetics of diabetes in pregnancy

item.title: METTL3 restrains autoimmunity in β-cells
item.description: Activation of innate immunity has been linked to the progression of type 1 diabetes. A study now shows that overexpression of METTL3, a writer protein of the m6A machinery that modifies mRNA, restrains interferon-stimulated genes when expressed in pancreatic β-cells, identifying it as a promising therapeutic target.

item.dc:creator: Balasubramanian Krishnamurthy

item.dc:title: METTL3 restrains autoimmunity in β-cells

item.title: Immunotherapy at all stages of hepatocellular carcinoma
item.description: A flurry of emerging treatment options is transforming the therapeutic landscape of hepatocellular carcinoma; two new studies highlight the complexities and gaps in knowledge, but also hint at a greater understanding of how to apply immunotherapy in early and advanced disease.

item.title: Disease resistance through M genes
item.description: Plants regulate their microbiota to cope with diverse stresses. A recent study shows that rice maintains homeostasis of its phyllosphere microbiome through a secondary metabolite biosynthetic gene, which offers potential for harnessing microbiome-shaping genes in disease-resistance breeding.

Mengcen Wang

item.title: Expanding the reach and scalability of perinatal mental health interventions
item.description: A new study shows the benefits of treating anxiety to prevent postnatal depression — and highlights the need for more pragmatic research to simplify treatment packages, address other comorbid symptoms, and deliver effective perinatal mental health care at scale.
item.content:encoded: A new study shows the benefits of treating anxiety to prevent postnatal depression — and highlights the need for more pragmatic research to simplify treatment packages, address other comorbid symptoms, and deliver effective perinatal mental health care at scale.
item.dc:creator: Daisy R. Singla
item.dc:title: Expanding the reach and scalability of perinatal mental health interventions

item.title: Lysosomal channels sensing forces
item.description: Mechanical forces are ubiquitously present in biology. In recent years, it has become clear how plasma membranes detect these forces — but how do intracellular organelles such as lysosomes do the same, and what might be the functions of such intracellular mechanosensing? Answers may come through a report of a lysosomal mechanosensitive ion channel, TMEM63.
item.content:encoded: Mechanical forces are ubiquitously present in biology. Answers may come through a report of a lysosomal mechanosensitive ion channel, TMEM63.
item.dc:creator: Erika Riederer
Dejian Ren
item.dc:title: Lysosomal channels sensing forces

item.title: Why reciprocity is common in humans but rare in other animals
item.description: Reciprocal cooperation can be advantageous, but why it is more common in humans than in other social animals is a puzzle. A modelling and experimental study pinpoints the conditions needed for reciprocity to evolve.
item.content:encoded: Reciprocal cooperation can be advantageous, but why it is more common in humans than in other social animals is a puzzle. A modelling and experimental study pinpoints the conditions needed for reciprocity to evolve.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mathew
item.dc:title: Why reciprocity is common in humans but rare in other animals

item.title: An innovative way for whales to sing
item.description: Mammals make sounds when air flow causes paired tissue folds in their voice box to oscillate. However, such air flow in the baleen group of whales takes an unusual path, enabling them to make sounds in a previously unknown way.
item.content:encoded: Mammals make sounds when air flow causes paired tissue folds in their voice box to oscillate. However, such air flow in the baleen group of whales takes an unusual path, enabling them to make sounds in a previously unknown way.
item.dc:creator: Joy S. Reidenberg
item.dc:title: An innovative way for whales to sing

item.title: Nanotraps boost light intensity for future optical devices
item.description: A method for configuring light-trapping devices promises better optical nanodevices by amplifying light and enhancing the emission efficiency of luminescent nanomaterials — without the need for complex technology upgrades.
item.content:encoded: A method for configuring light-trapping devices promises better optical nanodevices by amplifying light and enhancing the emission efficiency of luminescent nanomaterials — without the need for complex technology upgrades.

item.dc:title: Nanotraps boost light intensity for future optical devices

item.title: Rare isotopes formed in prelude to γ-ray burst
item.description: The afterglow of a long burst of γ-rays suggests that the events leading to these explosions can be sizeable sources of some of the Universe’s rare isotopes — and that classifications of γ-ray bursts are too simplistic.
item.content:encoded: The afterglow of a long burst of γ-rays suggests that the events leading to these explosions can be sizeable sources of some of the Universe’s rare isotopes — and that classifications of γ-ray bursts are too simplistic.

item.title: Light can restore a heart’s rhythm
item.description: Implantable electric pacemakers save millions of lives worldwide, but they aren’t perfect. A proof-of-concept study shows that using light to regulate a heartbeat might be a better option than existing strategies.
item.content:encoded: Implantable electric pacemakers save millions of lives worldwide, but they aren’t perfect. A proof-of-concept study shows that using light to regulate a heartbeat might be a better option than existing strategies.

item.dc:title: Light can restore a heart’s rhythm

item.title: Mapping T cell landscapes in B cell lymphomas
item.description: As a major microenvironmental component in B cell lymphomas, T cells are highly relevant for current immunotherapeutic treatment strategies of such tumours. A study now provides an unprecedented multimodal insight into the composition and features of T cell subsets of the four main types of nodal B cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

item.title: Layered ferroelectric materials make waves — and vortices
item.description: By combining materials-synthesis techniques, researchers have come up with a way of building layered structures that display intriguing wave-like patterns of electric polarization, and could be useful for next-generation electronics.

item.title: New type of magnetism splits from convention
item.description: Magnetic materials with zero net magnetization fall into two classes: conventional antiferromagnets and altermagnets. Physicists have identified a property in altermagnets that widens the divide between the two groups.
item.content:encoded: Magnetic materials with zero net magnetization fall into two classes: conventional antiferromagnets and altermagnets. Physicists have identified a property in altermagnets that widens the divide between the two groups.

item.title: Gender bias is more exaggerated in online images than in text
item.description: A big-data analysis shows that men are starkly over-represented in online images, and that gender bias is stronger in images compared with text. Such images could influence enduring gender biases in our offline lives.
item.content:encoded: A big-data analysis shows that men are starkly over-represented in online images, and that gender bias is stronger in images compared with text. Such images could influence enduring gender biases in our offline lives.

item.dc:title: Gender bias is more exaggerated in online images than in text

item.title: Smoking’s lasting effect on the immune system
item.description: It emerges from a study of human cells that smoking can influence certain immune responses to the same extent as can age or genetics. Smoking can alter the immune system in ways that persist long after quitting the habit.
item.content:encoded: It emerges from a study of human cells that smoking can influence certain immune responses to the same extent as can age or genetics. Smoking can alter the immune system in ways that persist long after quitting the habit.

item.title: Building chromatin from the ground up
item.description: A common architectural feature of the genome in many organisms is chromatin domains. A synthetic biology approach now builds chromatin domains from scratch and identifies some of the minimal components needed for their formation.

item.title: Delivering high-quality childbirth care
item.description: A pilot trial of the WHO’s Labour Care Guide reveals important considerations for implementation and for future trials aimed at reducing the inappropriate use of cesarean section, particularly in low- and middle-income countries.

item.title: mtDNA caught in the act again
item.description: Despite a growing understanding of the immunostimulatory properties of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), little is known about how and why mtDNA escapes its mitochondrial confines. A study now describes an endosomal trafficking pathway that facilitates mtDNA egress and provides an additional mechanism of mtDNA release in vitro.

item.title: Rejuvenation of diabetic macular edema with senolytic therapy
item.description: Senolytic therapy for diabetic macular edema (DME) refractory to anti-VEGF treatment appears safe, and preliminary data suggest a therapeutic effect on visual acuity and macular thickness.

item.title: Genetic analysis of cardiac dynamic flow volumes identifies loci mapping aortic root size
item.description: An open-source automated algorithm called DeepFlow enables large-scale derivation of aortic flow measurements, and genetic analysis of aortic flow, structural and functional traits demonstrates a causal relationship between aortic size and aortic valve regurgitation.

item.title: Connecting clinical and genetic heterogeneity in ADHD
item.description: Understanding clinical heterogeneity in attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is important for improving personalized care and long-term outcomes. A study exploits the large scale and breadth of phenotyping of the iPSYCH cohort to link clinical heterogeneity to genetic heterogeneity in ADHD.

item.title: Single-cell probing of RNA structure
item.description: sc-SPORT offers a way to probe RNA structure at the single-cell level. It reveals cell-to-cell heterogeneity in RNA folding.

item.title: Compositional plasticity of the Atg1 complex
item.description: How do metabolic stresses trigger catabolic autophagy for cell survival? A study now reveals that the metabolite sensor Pho81 integrates into and activates the kinase activity of the Atg1 complex for pexophagy triggered by phosphate starvation. This demonstrates the plasticity of the autophagy-initiating Atg1 complex.

item.title: An AI chatbot for talking therapy referrals
item.description: An AI-enabled chatbot increased self-referrals to psychological therapies for common mental health disorders; but further research is needed to ensure that better access translates into high-quality treatment experiences and outcomes for everyone.

item.title: Lipid remodelling in mammalian development
item.description: Lipids have a pivotal role in the growth of oocytes and fertilized eggs. Ultra-sensitive lipidome analysis provides a complete overview of the lipid profile during early embryonic development and brings insights into how dynamic lipid remodelling determines the fate of mammalian embryos.

item.title: An ancient psychedelic for traumatic brain injury
item.description: In military veterans with traumatic brain injury, treatment with ibogaine plus magnesium led to dramatic clinical improvements and a favorable safety profile; further studies with state-of-the art safety monitoring will be crucial to unlocking the potential benefits of this psychedelic compound.

item.title: Evidence for iatrogenic transmission of Alzheimer’s disease
item.description: Credible evidence suggests that, under extraordinary circumstances, Alzheimer’s disease may be transmitted by a prion-like mechanism — yielding insights into both the basic biology of this neurodegenerative disorder and strategies for early prevention.

item.title: Talking with force at cell–cell adhesions
item.description: Cell–cell adhesions are inevitably exposed to mechanical forces. A landmark paper by Yonemura et al. identified how tension alters molecular function of the cadherin adhesion apparatus. Its legacy lies in the many on-going efforts to understand how mechanical force is used in cell–cell communication.

item.title: The science of falls and how to prevent them
item.description: As populations age, falls are an increasing public health problem; strategies to prevent them should incorporate new technologies and insights into the sensory, perceptual and motor systems controlling balance.

item.title: Defining the chromatin signature of pluripotency
item.description: The interplay between DNA and its associated proteins has a crucial role in regulating gene expression and determining cellular identity. Here we revisit an earlier Nature Cell Biology study that established the chromatin signature associated with pluripotency.

item.title: The rules of the totipotency treasure hunt
item.description: Totipotency is the absence of any developmental restriction, a feature naturally found in the early embryo right after fertilization. Generating an in vitro totipotent stem cell model is not a trivial task. For this reason, a set of stringent criteria for the identification of bona fide totipotent stem cells have been proposed.

item.dc:title: The rules of the totipotency treasure hunt

item.title: A milestone in epithelial–mesenchymal transition
item.description: Epithelial–mesenchymal transition (EMT) is crucial in embryogenesis and can be exploited by cancer cells to gain metastatic abilities. A hallmark of EMT is E-cadherin loss. In 2000, Snail was reported as the first E-cadherin repressor identified in the context of EMT, advancing our understanding of embryonic development and cancer progression.

item.title: Extracellular vesicles, genetic programmers
item.description: Extracellular vesicles carry proteins and lipids between cells. In a giant step forward for the field, a 2007 study published in Nature Cell Biology showed that secreted vesicles contain genetic material that is active within acceptor cells, reviving interest in extracellular vesicle-based communication in plant and animal biology.

item.title: Reading banned regions of genomes
item.description: The effect of DNA methylation on gene expression has been known for decades. However, the mechanism by which DNA methylation functions to repress transcription has remained a major question in the field. Wang et al. now narrow this gap through their examination of the methylation binding protein MBD2 and expose how DNA methylation is read upstream of transcriptional repression.

item.title: Cell origin of BRCA2-mutant breast cancer
item.description: The different compartments of the mammary stem cell hierarchy develop into distinct breast cancer subtypes as a result of specific genetic lesions. A recent study identifies aberrant ERBB3low luminal progenitors with altered proteostasis and translation as the cell of origin of BRCA2-mutant breast cancer.

item.title: The grand challenge of moving cancer whole-genome sequencing into the clinic
item.description: The largest whole-genome sequencing study thus far has revealed myriad actionable alterations and potential biomarkers for 33 cancer types, but various logistical, technical and economic challenges must be overcome before this technique can become standard of care.

item.title: Integrating vaccines and monoclonal antibodies into malaria prevention
item.description: Two malaria vaccines are approved and several prophylactic antibodies are in development, but a combination of strategies tailored to different epidemiological situations will be needed if malaria is to be eliminated.

item.title: EPAC1 boosts thermogenic adipocyte formation
item.description: β-adrenergic signalling induces thermogenesis in mature brown adipocytes through a well-known cAMP–protein kinase A (PKA) pathway and also promotes the growth and differentiation of new thermogenic adipocytes. A study now demonstrates that β-adrenergic agonists drive this pathway through a PKA-independent mechanism involving cAMP–EPAC1.

A study now demonstrates that β-adrenergic agonists drive this pathway through a PKA-independent mechanism involving cAMP–EPAC1.

item.title: tRNA flux and consistency in differentiation
item.description: tRNA transcriptome composition and regulation are poorly understood. A study reports tRNA transcriptome reprogramming during human cell differentiation, where the abundance of individual tRNA gene transcripts is drastically changed, but each pool of tRNAs containing the same anticodon remains stable.

item.title: FUS maintains TAZ fluidity and function
item.description: The transcriptional coactivators TAZ and YAP pair with transcriptional enhanced associate domains (TEADs) to regulate transcription. TAZ and YAP nuclear condensates ensure optimal transcription. A new study reports that FUS regulates TAZ condensates by maintaining them in a fluid state to drive transcription of target genes.

item.title: Microbial regulation of ferroptosis in cancer
item.description: Different gut microbial metabolites have the potential to promote and protect against colorectal cancer (CRC). A study now links trans-3-indoleacrylic acid (IDA), a metabolite derived from Peptostreptococcus anaerobius, with colorectal carcinogenesis through a distinct ferroptosis pathway AHR–ALDH1A3–FSP1–CoQ10.

item.title: Tackling inappropriate antibiotic use in low-and middle-income countries
item.description: New data show that electronic clinical decision support systems integrated with point-of-care tests can lead to meaningful reductions in antibiotic use in children in low- and middle-income countries, without compromising health outcomes — but investment in human resources is crucial to their success.

item.title: Cell perturbation and lasers illuminate the genetics of latent blood cell traits
item.description: A new study combining experimental treatments of human blood cells from thousands of individuals with flow-cytometry-based phenotyping and then genome-wide association analyses identifies genetic loci associated with non-resting cell states. Integrating the results with disease association signals yields insights into the underlying biology.

item.title: Charting multicellular tissue structure cell-to-cell
item.description: The spatial biology revolution promises deep insights into tissue organization, but deriving this knowledge from diverse, complex data remains a major obstacle. Data-driven discovery of the multicellular organization of tissues is now achieved by transforming multimodal spatial imaging data using deep learning.

item.title: Extraordinary collateral mutagenesis induced by CX-5461
item.description: CX-5461 (also known as pidnarulex), currently in phase 1/2 trials, induces selective killing of homologous-recombination-deficient or BRCA1- or BRCA2-mutated tumors in preclinical models. New work confirms these findings but shows it to be a remarkably potent mutagen that induces extensive genetic changes in cultured human cells with or without BRCA1/2 mutations, raising substantial safety issues.
item.content:encoded: CX-5461 (also known as pidnarulex), currently in phase 1/2 trials, induces selective killing of homologous-recombination-deficient or BRCA1- or BRCA2-mutated tumors in preclinical models. New work confirms these findings but shows it to be a remarkably potent mutagen that induces extensive genetic changes in cultured human cells with or without BRCA1/2 mutations, raising substantial safety issues.

item.title: RNA polymerase II promoter-proximal pausing promotes BAF chromatin binding and remodeling
item.description: New research reports that paused RNA polymerase II (RNAPII) enhances the targeting and activity of BAF chromatin remodelers. These findings suggest a new paradigm for understanding how the collaborative action of chromatin remodelers and the transcriptional machinery govern cell-type-specific chromatin accessibility.

item.title: Dissecting organelle interdependence
item.description: The structures and functions of organelles are highly interdependent. Using paired 3D electron microscopy and multi-omics, a study now shows how other organelles affect mitochondrial structure and function: peroxisome-derived lipids reverse mitochondrial stress, highlighting the importance of organelle interconnectivity.

item.title: Shared chromosomal segments connect ancient human societies
item.description: Long segments of the genome that are shared ‘identical by descent’ (IBD) demonstrate recent relatedness between individuals. A new computational method robustly identifies shared IBD segments in human ancient DNA data, providing insights into the mobility and demography of prehistoric human societies.

item.title: Engineered nanopores for exopeptidase protein sequencing
item.description: Two studies show that nanopores can identify the 20 proteinogenic amino acids and some of their post-translational modifications. Coupled with an exopeptidase, a bottom-up approach to protein sequencing using nanopores is on the horizon.

item.title: Implementing plans for global elimination of cervical cancer

item.title: Assembling neuroactive alkaloids
item.description: The Lycopodium alkaloids represent a valuable source of neuroactive compounds. The biosynthesis of these specialized metabolites is now shown to involve three α-carbonic anhydrase-like enzymes that are responsible for constructing the key carbon–carbon bonds within their distinctive polycyclic alkaloid structures.

item.title: Structural biology in the age of AI

item.title: Taming the HLA for single-cell genomics
item.description: Variants in the HLA region on chromosome 6 are strongly associated with many immune-related diseases. A method to construct personalized HLA genomes from single-cell RNA sequencing data, coupled with single-cell HLA expression quantitative trait loci modeling, identifies how genetic variants influence HLA gene expression across cell states.

item.title: Current approaches to genomic deep learning struggle to fully capture human genetic variation
item.description: Deep learning shows promise for predicting gene expression levels from DNA sequences. However, recent studies show that current state-of-the-art models struggle to accurately characterize expression variation from personal genomes, limiting their usefulness in personalized medicine.

item.title: New ingredients for old recipes

A study now demonstrates that a primate-specific regulatory network controlled by the KRAB zinc-finger protein ZNF808 is essential for pancreas development.

item.description: Brain somatic mosaicism is linked to several neurological disorders and is thought to arise post-zygotically. A study suggests that pre-zygotic aneuploidy followed by post-zygotic partial reversion leads to a recurrent form of brain mosaicism-related epilepsy.

item.title: The power paradox of detecting disease-associated and gene-expression-associated variants
item.description: The mechanisms of many disease-associated variants are uncertain because of limited power to detect their modest effects on gene expression. This study finds that natural selection leads to preferential detection of disease-associated versus expression-associated variants.

item.title: Polycomb repression of the asexual embryo
item.description: In angiosperms, the proliferation and differentiation of egg and central cells need to be repressed before fertilization. Autonomous endosperm development has been observed and well-studied in Arabidopsis mutants of FERTILIZATION INDEPENDENT SEED (FIS)-class POLYCOMB REPRESSIVE COMPLEX 2 (PRC2), but how defects of PRC2 components affect embryo development remains unclear. Wu et al. now describe an essential clue for understanding parthenogenetic embryogenesis from the rice double mutant osfie1 osfie2.

Wu et al. now describe an essential clue for understanding parthenogenetic embryogenesis from the rice double mutant osfie1 osfie2.

item.title: Tumor heterogeneity impairs immunogenicity in mismatch repair deficient tumors
item.description: DNA mismatch repair deficiency (MMRd) is associated with elevated tumor mutational burden (TMB) and exceptional immunotherapy responses, yet some patients experience no clinical benefit. Recent work proposes that high intra-tumoral heterogeneity can offset immunogenicity in sporadic MMRd, suggesting a potential mechanism of immunotherapy failure.

item.title: FER meets the Nod factor pathway
item.description: Single-nucleus transcriptomic analysis of Medicago roots reveals dynamic cell-specific responses to the Nod factor — a bacterially secreted chito-lipopolysaccharide with a key role in the root nodule symbiosis between legumes and rhizobia — and identifies the receptor-like kinase FERONIA as a phosphorylation target of the Nod factor receptor LYK3, which together function to control nodule formation and bacterial infection.

item.title: How to establish a GAPLESS Casparian strip
item.description: To control the movement of water and nutrients, vascular plants seal the paracellular space between adjacent endodermal cells with a tight junction-like complex comprising the Casparian strip and Casparian strip membrane domain. In rice, GAPLESS proteins mediate the attachment of these two components and enable nutrient homeostasis.

item.title: Inflammation drives pressure on TP53 mutant clones in myeloproliferative neoplasms
item.description: Transformation of a myeloproliferative neoplasm to a secondary acute myeloid leukemia is rare but devastating. item.title: The power of repetition
item.description: The inclusion of retrotransposon long terminal repeats — and of other repeated sequences — enhances transfer DNA copy numbers in plant cells during transformation. Gene editing and homologous recombination-mediated gene targeting can therefore be improved by these means: however, the mechanism remains a mystery.

item.title: Advancing multiplexed imaging for enhanced tissue complexity analysis
item.description: Multiplexed spatial immunophenotyping has advanced our understanding of tissues in the context of homeostasis and disease. Two studies now provide additional tools to overcome challenges with multiplexed imaging: one procedure amplifies the detection of low-abundance antigens by integrating SABER and IMC technologies, and the other is an X-ray-based method that enables the non-destructive multiplexed detection of antigens in tissues at scalable resolution and speed.

item.title: Measuring open chromatin and DNA methylation in repeat arrays
item.description: Highly repetitive regions such as centromeres bedevilled genome assembly for decades until a recent flurry of gapless genome publications. Attention is now focused on interpreting the chromatin within these most repetitive regions, as illustrated by a new paper on simultaneously measuring open chromatin and DNA methylation using long-read sequencing.
item.content:encoded: Highly repetitive regions such as centromeres bedevilled genome assembly for decades until a recent flurry of gapless genome publications. Attention is now focused on interpreting the chromatin within these most repetitive regions, as illustrated by a new paper on simultaneously measuring open chromatin and DNA methylation using long-read sequencing.

item.title: Silencing translation with phenolic acids
item.description: Phenolic acids, such as salicylic acid, are part of a mechanism that helps to suppress the growth of neighbouring plants. New work shows that phenolic acids inhibit global translation by promoting the sequestration of ribosomal subunits into stress granules.
item.content:encoded: Phenolic acids, such as salicylic acid, are part of a mechanism that helps to suppress the growth of neighbouring plants. New work shows that phenolic acids inhibit global translation by promoting the sequestration of ribosomal subunits into stress granules.

item.title: Opening the gates
item.description: A new study reveals that epigenetic mechanism mediates temperature control of callose synthase expression to regulate opening of plasmodesmata and facilitate bud sprouting in lilies.

item.title: On the origin of strawberries
item.description: High-quality genomes of the cultivated strawberry’s progenitors provide the strongest evidence to date for the identity and chromosomal composition of the four subgenomes of octoploid strawberry.

item.title: Dissecting gene regulation with multimodal sequencing
item.description: Recently proposed computational approaches explore casual links between chromatin and transcriptional changes that are provided by single-cell multimodal sequencing to bridge the knowledge gap in transcriptional regulatory control.

item.title: A light switch for DNA break repair
item.description: Organisms have developed specialized and intricate mechanisms to cope with environmental threats that depend on their natural habitat and ability to move. Arabidopsis demonstrates an impressive adaptation using cryptochrome 1 to maintain genomic stability through a blue-light-mediated process that involves the recruitment of repair proteins to double-strand breaks.

Arabidopsis demonstrates an impressive adaptation using cryptochrome 1 to maintain genomic stability through a blue-light-mediated process that involves the recruitment of repair proteins to double-strand breaks.

item.title: Microbiome-mediated metabolic defence
item.description: The destructive panicle disease rice false smut is caused by the biotrophic fungus Ustilaginoidea virens. Disease-suppressive microorganisms present in rice panicles have now been found to mediate fungal resistance by modulating the metabolism of the host plant.

item.title: Lighting up action potentials with fast and bright voltage sensors

item.title: Dynamic nucleoskeleton in stress
item.description: The nucleoskeleton maintains nuclear integrity and chromatin organization at the inner nuclear surface. Here, Wang et al. revealed a disassociation of nuclear skeleton proteins from the nuclear periphery upon heat stress, which affects genome architecture and alters gene expression.

item.title: IMAGE-seq and you shall find
item.description: Integration of single-cell molecular profiling with cellular spatial localization has remained an elusive goal. Image-seq leverages high-resolution microscopy to spatially resolve and isolate viable bone marrow and leukemia cells for subsequent state-of-the art, single-cell transcriptomics.

item.title: Facilitating genome structural variation analysis
item.description: Although structural variation is less explored than single-nucleotide variation, recent studies have shown it to be associated with several human diseases. Three fresh computational methods might help to elucidate this inadequately understood part of our genetic makeup.
